TEI:
Title
Publication Information
Information about the source
Newspaper clippings and photographs documenting motorsports in 1950s Ireland collected and bound in a scrapbook by Ian Williams. Digitised by Jackie Williams and Elisabeth Nonstad for archival, preservation and publication purposes.
Spelling errors not corrected, content only added if the page was damaged and it was possible to ascertain what was missing. Punctuation kept as in the original text.
A scrapbook containing newspaper clippings and photographs documenting the experiences of Ian Williams in his motorcross days in Dublin, Ireland, in the 1950's.
Dublin, Ireland c. 1956
Original text in blue ink, written by Ian Williams.

CHAMPIONSHIP CHALLENGER . . .
Dublin rider Ian Williams (Ariel) who rides in to-morrow’s Hurst Cup International Trial at Conling, Belfast.
Hurst Cup Trial Has
Big English Entry
By BASIL BRINDLEY
A black and white image, which is loacted at the top, centre of the article, of two motorcycle racers; Ian Williams (foreground), who is raising up the front wheel of his bike, and an unidentified man (background).
CHAMPIONSHIP CHALLENGER . . .
Dublin rider Ian Williams (Ariel) who rides in to-morrow’s Hurst Cup International Trial at Conling, Belfast.
Hurst Cup Trial Has
Big English Entry
By BASIL BRINDLEY
>>>>>>> parent of 1329f95 (Update Master_TEI.xml)
WITH an entry of 79 for to-morrow’s Hurst Cup Trial,
officials of the Knock Motor Cycle Club must be
feeling very happy, as 80 is the maximum figure
specified on the regulations.
The international event
will be held over a number of
laps in the Clandeboye
Estate, Belfast, and total
distance will be somewhat
less than 50 miles.
English competitors did excep-
tionally well last year and,
judging by the increase in their
numbers on this occasion, they
intend to return with the valuable
perpetual trophy for another 12
months.
The Sunbeam Motor Cycle Club
is responsible for no less than
seven members of the eighteen-
strong cross -Channel challenge.
Included in this team are Johnny
Brittain (Royal Enfield), P. H.
Alves (Triumph), B. W. Martin
(B.S.A.) and the Wicken brothers
who will be Norman and Triumph-
mounted.
Scotsman J. H. Birrell has entered
a junior "Gold Star" while other
visitors of note are E. Usher (Match-
less), G. L. Jackson (A.J.S.), E. W.
Smith (Francis Barnett) and J. V.
Smith (B.S.A.)
Leinster will be represented by
practically every outstanding rider in
the province and regulars like Dudley
Ryder (Matchless), Joe Dawson
(B.S.A.), Mick Tracey (Norton),
Freddie Dickson (Sun) and Kevin
Keegan (B.S.A.) may be relied upon
to acquit themselves well.
>>>>>>> parent of 1329f95 (Update Master_TEI.xml)
Strong Ulster Bid
Travelling up from the south also
with good reputations are Dave
Felton (Francis Barnett), Ian
Williams, Reg Armstrong (Gilera)
and James exponents Ernie Lyons,
Doug Ewen and Aubrey Archer.
With over 50 p.c. of the entry,
Ulster is in a strong position and
if a Six-County man is to win the
event, it’s odds on Sammy Miller
from Belfast being the one to do
it. Riding a 197 c.c, James, this
road racing and trials star has
proved himself almost invincible
during the season and he must
have an outstanding chance to-
morrow.
Able support will come from Bill
Clark (Royal Enfield). Tommy Robb
(Francis Barnett), W. J. Hutton
(Greeves), Terry Hill (B.S.A.), Brian
McClery (Royal Enfield) and Bertie
Mann (Francis Barnett), all of whom
have been figuring well in this year’s
events.
The trial begins at 12 o’clock and
starting point is near the Lead Mines,
Conling.

deserved,he was placed at every

20 1/2 points. Runner-up is Ernie Lyons who won the cup

1/2 points; followed by D. C. Ewen, 8 points; F
C. Coard, E. Callaghan and M. Tracey with 6 points.
Slade Scramble By BASIL BRINDLEY
LONG handicap man, Stan Tracey,
scored a comfortable win from
the near scratch pair, Freddie Dickson
and Edmund Gill, in the Nicholson
Memorial Scramble at, the Slade
yesterday.
The event was run over fifteen laps
and was preceded by the
distance Carville Cup race,
honours went to C. Sun- F. C. Dickson, E. Rice.
Triumph-S. Spence, P. H. Alves,
J. Giles, J. E. Wicken.

SMILES FROM DAVID TYE AND MYSELF AT BRAY SCRAMBLE
Ian Williams
Beats Brother
IAN WILLIAMS returned to grass
track racing in sparkling form
and at the Dublin University grass
track races at Powerscourt yester-
day his victories included an
exciting finish in the handicap final
where he beat his brother Eric by
half a wheel.
by
half a wheel.

Surface 3_1 of page 3 (sb_06) A black and white photograph of a man (possibly Ian Williams) rides a motorcycle (marked number 5), which has it's front and back wheels lifted off the ground, over a rocky path.
Surface 3_2 of page 3 (sb_06) A cut out newspaper article.
12 Irish Independent, Wednesday, October 3, 1956
Motor Sport Review
Moto-Cross Was
Great Success
BY BARRY MASON
THE outstanding success of the
Dublin and District Motor Cycle
Club's Moto-Cross last Saturday
indicated that there is a bright
future in this country for such
an event
Irish riders’ lack of practice was
obvious and if they are to hold
their own in the future there must
be more events for training. It was
very interesting to see how quickly
some of them "caught on” last Satur-
day. The outstanding Irish competi-
tor was Ian Williams, who has had
some experience recently in Eng-
land, where he was riding for the
Ariel factory.
The most obvious things that
our men have to learn are. keep-
ing the taps open and front wheel
control. It was wonderful to see
how the British experts could con-
trol their bikes at higher speeds
than those at which many of our
men were losing control of their
machines.
Front wheel lifting seems to be
the answer. At one particularly
tricky point, the course crossed a
lane. Here the less experienced were
“ jumping ” their machines at the
start of the crossing, landing on the
far side of the lane and “ jumping ”
a second time
MUCH QUICKER
THE experts took it much faster,
cleared the lot with one jump
and landed on the back wheel,
keeping the front wheel off the
ground until they had things
perfectly under control.
Alex Woods was another of
Irish competitors who showed up
well earning fourth place in the
350 race and fifth, after Williams,
in the 500 race on his fast 350
machine. Ernie Lyons did well to
drive a “wedge” amongst the four
Dot works men in the 250 race but
it appeared to me that his N.S.U.
did not have the speed of the Dots,
and he appeared to tire, possibly through having to work so hard
with a slower machine.
The surprise of the meeting was
the great improvement in the riding
of Eric Williams, brother of Ian.
His win in the handicap was well
merited.
Revenue is a big difficulty for
clubs here as the big events are
road races where no admission
charge is possible, but I think that
more events of the Moto-Cross
variety, which are run on enclosed
circuits where a charge can be col-
lected, may at least be part of the
answer.
BIG ATTENDANCE
THIS type of sport is a novelty to
Irish people, but there was
quite a big attendance on Satur-
day, and as word gets around as
to its value its appeal will
increase.
I know that the calendar is
already very full, but it might be
worth while dropping some other
events in favour of the Moto-Cross,
and now is the time to plan.
With the last of the racing season
events on Saturday, the 5OO
M.R.C.I. car meeting in Ulster, the
trials season opens in a big way
this month.
For bikes there are three champion-
ship trials in October, the Belfast and
District Club’s, Barr Trophy (6th),
the Dublin and District Club’s,
Moran Cup (13th), and the Ulster
President’s Cup (27th).
On Saturday in the Dublin area
there is the Dublin University Club’s,
Fall Trial, starting from Lamb
Doyles (3.0). For cars on Saturday
there is the Leinster Club’s, Vigzol
Cup Trial, a non-observed event,
starting from the Phoenix Monument
(3.0).
On Sunday there is the first of the
trials counting towards this season’s
Hewison Trophy competition, the
Limerick Club’s Circuit of Clare,
which this year takes the place in
the series of the same club’s Circuit
of Munster. The other Hewison event
this month is the Kilkenny Winter
Trial (28th).
Surface 4_1 of page 4 (sb_08) A newspaper article cutting.
Dublin And District Motor
Cycle Club Had Day Out
CONGRATULATIONS to the Dublin and District Motor Cycle
Club whose International Moto Cross meeting on Saturday
last was one of the most entertaining fixtures of the season.
the course at Redbog was ideally suited for this sport and many
of the English works ridersdescribed it as one of the
best in Europe.
In the light og such an enthusi-
astic reception it is now very much
more than a possibility that next
year's meeting will be included on
the world championship table with
the result that we may have a
unique invasion of manufacturers
teams including leading English
and Continental exponents.
As expected the B.S.A and the Dot
nominees made a clean sweep in
the last three scratch races on Satur-
day last but quite a few names were made by Irishmen whose pre-
vious experience was gained from
dabbling in other branches of the
game together with a mere handful
of scrambles.
Perhaps the most impressive was
Harry O'Reilly's son, Frank, who
rode his Lightweight Tandon with
an unbounded exuberance which
made quite a few of the stars, and
in particular Bill Barugh og the
Dot team, sit up and take note
After figuring prominently in the
qualifying heat Frank put every-
thing he knew into the final and
going into the lead on the third lap
he stayed in front until the last half mile where he was headed by
Eric Williams on the Mountjoy
entered Ariel.
FIGURED PROMINENTLY
If he continues to improve at
the present rate there is little
doubt that Frank O'Reilly could
turn out to be a really top class
Moto Cross and Road Racing star
He has certainly put his Grasstrack
experience to great use and his long distance road racing debut on the Brian Somers B.S.A at this
year's Skerries "100" gave some indication of the Dubliner's ability
The Williams brothers, Ian and
Eric also caught the eye on Saturday
last and both of them figured promi-
nently in the awards list. Indeed
were it not for the fact that Eric
had shown such a terrific improve-
ment in his riding he could never
have overhauled Frank O'Reilly in
order to capture the Freeman Trophy in the general handicap final.
Ian, who rode at several cross
Channel meetings last season was
the fastest Irishman of the dat as
he took Ted Barret's other Ariel into
fourth place in the Senior scratch
race despite a heavy tumbe en route
He also occupied a similar position
in the general handicap and con
sidering that he was riding off such
a short mark of one and a half
minutes he did extremely well to get the flag so near to Brian Stone-
bridge the B.S.A expert.
The evergreen Ernie Lyons gave
the huge crowds plenty to enthuse
over in the 250 c.c. event and his
fourth position behind three of the
Dot men and in front of another
of them calls for honourable men-
tion Unfortunately Freddie Dixon
who was also expected to do well in
the same event broke his frame on
the first lap and took no further
part in the proceedings
NORTHERN SUCCESSES
Several Ulster riders hit the
headlines during the afternoon.
the most successful of them being
Alex McFarland Woods from Bel-
fast who finished fourth to the B.S.A. team in the 350 c.c. scratch
race fifth to Ian Williams and the
same trio in the Senior event and
sixth in the genereal handicap all on a Junior 'Gold Star".
Alan Bradshaw made news with his
Francis-Barnett when taking a very
creditable sixth in the opening en-
counter and he finished up the day
as eight man home in the general
handicap with a comparatively
short allowance of one lap.
The Car Trials season gets into its
stride this weekend when the Lein-
ster Motor Club holds it Vigzol Cup
meeting over a 60 mile course start-
ing in the Phoenix Park at 3 p.m
on Saturday. Navigation by Ordnance
Survey sheets No. 16 and 13 will play
an important part in prodeedings
and references by the old and new
grid system will be supplied to com
petitors
Sunday's Circuit of Clare T
which starts from Limerick at
a.m. wukk narj tge beginning of the
Hewison Trophy competition and
because of this all leading Dublin
and Provincial enthusiasts are ex-
pected to make the journey for this
well supported fixture.

WILLIAMS BROTHERS IN FORM
The Dublin University Club held a grass-
track race meeting in Powerscourt on Satur-
day. The Williams Brother had a good
day with three wins and three places between
them. Ian Williams and Ernie Lyons again
had some close tussles, Lyons winning the
graded scratch race and Williams the 500
c.c. scratch in the best time of the day.

(James), 5m. 28. s.; 2. G.T. Nolan (James);
3. D. Hughes (James).

(Ariel), 2s.; 3. G.T. Scarlett (Sun), 35s.

Terrific Motor
Cycle Finish
HIGHLIGHT of the Dun
Laoghaire motor cycle
club's grass track meeting at
Rochestown Avenue yesterday
was a terrific neck - and - neck
struggle between Ian Williams
(Ariel) and Mervyn Hayes (Royal
Enfield) in the senior race. For
lap after lap the pair fought it
out. Williams got the verdict by
a fraction of a second.
500 c.c. Scr. – 1, I. Williams (Ariel);
2. M. Hayes (Royal Enfield); 3, E.
Williams (Ariel).
350 c.c. Class – 1, D. Dixon (Jap);
2. M. Foran (B.S.A); 3, D. Byrne
(B.S.A).
250 c.c. Class – 1, H. Buchanan

The sky's the limit . . . so thinks Ian
Williams as he directs his Arielinto space.
WILLIAMS'S TREBLE
At the Dublin University Motor-cycle
and Light Car Club's grass- track race meeting,
held in Powerscourt, Co. Wicklow, on
Saturday. Ian Williams (Ariel) scored a
treble and made fastest time of the day.
Other winners included C.F. Scarlett,
who won two events. Results:–

(Excelsior); 2. M. D. Thornton (Dot); 3,

lett (Dot), 2. F. C. Dickinson (Dot); 3,
J. Barkley (Sun)., 5 mins. 28 secs.

(Ariel), 2. E. Williams (Ariel); 3,
D. J.
Dixon (Norton/Jap). 5 mins. 5 secs.

Williams (Ariel), scr.; 2. E. Williams
(Ariel), h'cap 5 secs.; 3, G. F. Scarlett
(Dot), 18 secs. 5 mins. 0 secs.

(Dot); 2. F.C. Dickinson (Dot); 3, D.
Pearson(N.S.U.) 5 mins, 17 secs.

(Norton/Jap); 2. S. Foody (B.S.A.); 3,

Surface 7_1 of page 7 (sb_11) A black and white photograph of two men racing across a field on motorcyles. Shot from behind.
Surface 7_2 of page 7 (sb_11) A balck and white photograph of two men racing motorbikes as a crowd watches from the sidelines. The mortorbike in the lead (left) is marked number '38', the motorbike in the second position (right) is marked number'39'.
Surface 7_3 of page 7 (sb_11) A newspaper clipping.
B.S.A. Works Team For
D. And D. Meeting
B.S.A.’s have just announced their
intention of sending over an
official works team for the Dublin
and District Motor Cycle Club’s
International Moto Cross meeting
over the new course at Red Bog
later in the month and this news
will certainly give a terrific boost
to the already highly interesting
programme.
The Birmingham factory will be
represented by the high ranking
English stars, Brian Stonebridge,
David Tye and Terry Cheshire all
of whom will be supplied with
Senior and Junior " Gold Stars.”
Cheshire and Tye were both seen
in action at the Curragh last year,
but Stonebridge, who is in the
world championship class will be
making his first appearance on our
soil.
Enquiries have also been received
from Dutch and German riders and
it is quite possible that a number
of them will make the trip to
Ireland immediately after the con-
clusion of the International Six
Days’ Trial on the Continent.
Well-known Ulster men already
included in the colourful line-up are
Alex McFarland-Woods, Brian Cross
and Alan Bradshaw while the cross-
Channel Dot team have asked for
special permission to compete in all
classes. Fortunately there is a
clause in the regulations which
makes a proviso giving visitors a
special concession in this respect so
that Bill Barugh and his team
mates will be able to face the
starter as often as they wish.
And indeed, judging by some of
their outstanding performances in the past, it is safe to say that
these 197 c.c. two-strokers will be
more than a match for many of
their heavyweight rivals.
One of the strongest Irish teams
should be the Ariel trio, nominated
by Mr. Ted Barrett, of Mountjoy
Motor Cycles, Ltd. This very fast
line-up consists of Des. Cullen and
the Williams’ brothers, Ian and Eric,
who have been riding with such dis-
tinction during the past few seasons.
The Phibsboro’ sponsor has always
been very closely connected with the
sport, and any successes gained by
his B.S.A. or Ariel nominees have
been very well received by followers
of all branches of the game.
Most of the leading Dublin expo-
nents have already sent in their
entries, but it should be noted that
the list will finally close on Satur-
day, and no late entries can possibly
be considered after that date. In-
deed. by the looks of things, it may
well happen that some prospective
competitors will have to be included
amongst the reserves if nominations
continue to pour in at the present.
Surface 8_1 of page 8 (sb_15) A black and white photograph of two men racing motorcycles. Ian Williams (foreground) and another unidentified racer (background)
Surface 8_2 of page 8 (sb_15) A two column newspaper cutting.
Surface 8_3 of page 8 (sb_15) A black and white photograph of a motorcycle racer; Ian Williams.
MOTOR CYCLE AND SCOOTER NOTES
The best Last.
For some reason, as yet un-
explained, the graded scratch
raceswhich normally open the pro-
gramme, where the last events to be
contested at Sunday's open grass
track, organised by the Dalcassian
M.C.C., and run over an entirely
new course at Clonmoney, bun-
ratty. And, whereas the official pro-
gramme proclaimed that four of
these events should be run, in fact, there were only two.
It was the second and fastest of these that the finest
racing of the season so far was
witnessed. For nearly three laps, Willie Harris, that most likeable
lanky County Dublin farmer – whose
extreme shyness in company con-
trasts strangely with his tigerish
determination in the saddle – held
an incredible lead over Mervyn
Hayes and Ian Williams. The
magnitudeof Harris's achievement
will be obvious when it is realised
that both Williams and Hayes
straddled highly specialised J.A.P.
engined grasstrack specials of 500
c.c., while Harris was mounted on a
virtually standard–though admit-
dely dope-burning – Gold Star B.S.A. of only 350 c.c.
Eventually, both J.A.P.'s got past the B.S.A. and spectator interest
shifted from incredulous admira-
tion of Harris's David versus
Goliath act, to palpitations appre-
hension regarding the outcome of
the fierce struggle between Wil-
liams and Hayes. For two laps
Williams, unused to defeat in any
class, strove mightily to get past
his opponent, who enjoyed the ad-
vantage of an early lead. But
Hayes, one of the jolliest of men,
grinning impishly all the time, was
as willing to ride on the verge of
disaster as the other, and won
narrowly. The gallant Harris was third.... This was a great race! * * *
The Other Events.
Only less exciting by comparison
with such heart-stopping stuff
were the other events on the pro-
gramme. Ian Williams had dam-
aged the rear suspension of his
fleet Barnett in practice, and was a
non-starter in the 250 class, as
were the Freddie Dickson-Geary
Scarlet Dot equippe, who failed to
turn up, so the reliable Jimmy
Kavanagh had a little troulbe in
bringing his Francis Barnett (the
only one in the country besides
William's) into first place.
He was followed hime by Michael
Smurfit on the screaming Dodder
(a twin-cylinder Akder engine in a
Dot frame). Third place went to
Limerick's Don Kelly on the ex-
Harrington James. There wasn't
much real opposition in this class
– Tommy Griffin's Excelsior was
windbroken. Corkman Pat O'Shea's Jawa-engined special was temper-
amental. and, despite neat riding,
Joe MacMahon could do little on
an underpowered James.
* * *
* * *
Spills and Other Things
Ian Williams beat Mervyn Hayes
in the 500 c.c. scratch race. Eric
Williams, on another J.A.P, was a
comfortable second until he spilled.
George Harris was a good third.
Two lads from Cork Club found
their way into the Munster riders'
handicap, and took first and second
places, after Don Kelly, who was leading by a street, spilled through
over-eagerness. Actually the Naas
men should not have been allowed
to ride in this event, which was
originally intended for residents in
the province of Munster only. That
remark is not intended to belittle
the achievement of Con Hederman,
who also took first place in the
all-comer's handicap, in which event
Dermot Byrne of Dublin, out for the first time since sustaining a thumb
injury at the last Dalcassian meet-
ing in Nenagh, took second place,
as well as winning his heat.
* * *
Byrne, in fact, had a real field
day, because he also took first
place in graded scratch race A,
and Limerick's Dan Kelly had the
distinction of running into more
places than any other rider. Of
the remaining Limerickmen, Mick
MacEoin was foolish enough to
meddle in a major way with his
peak-conquering James on the day
before the event, in quest of more
speed, with the result that the un-
fortunate engine gave up the ghost
of Sunday during the first practice
lap. Matt Murphy did his best with
the same detuned James as Joe
McMahon.
The Automobile Association sign-
posing was, if anything, better
than ever, and the Red Cross and
Garda Siochana played their ex-
pected reliable parts Without
these and other voluntary helpers,
including the timekeepers, Mr. and
Mrs. and the Misses O'Reilly, it
would be impossible to run a de-
cent grasstrack. May their gener-
osity be rewarded!
* * *
250 c.c. (scr.)–J. M. Kavanagh
(Dublin) (247 Francis Barnet), 1;
M Smurfit (Dublin) (247 Dodder),
2; D. Kelly(Limerick) (197 James),
3. 4.56

dalkin) (B.S.A.), 1; J.L. Hickey
(Naas) (B.S.A.), 2; K. Hilton
(Dublin) (B.S.A.), 4. 4.37.

After the grasstrack, the awards
were presented in the Desmond
Hotel by Ald. G.E. Russel, T.D.,
Hon. President of the Dalcassians

Few finishers
in scrambles
HEAVY rain made the going
difficult in yesterday's Dublin
District Motor Cycle Club's
les at Red Bog, near
Blessington. and the distance of
the races was shortened.
Even then there were very few
finishers: in the main event
only eight finished out of 23
starters.
One of the two Belfast visitors,
Brian Cross (B.S.A.), won the
second graded scratch race, the
third going to Ian Williams
(Francis-Barnett), who made best
lap of the day in 3 m. 56 s. In the
open handicap he made a fast
start aand then retired.
Bob Thompson (Triumph), who
had won the first scratch race,
led the handicap from a long mark
for eight of the ten laps and then
ran into trouble. Brian Lamb. the
only surviving backmarker, came
right through the field and took
the lead on lap nine to win by
nearly two minutes. Results:–
Graded Scratch Race No. 1 (3
laps) – R. R. Thompson. 199 Triumph.
17 m. 27 s., 1; M. Flynn. 347 Match-
less, 18 m. 26 s., 2: G. D. Dixon, 197
Dot, 18 m. 36 s., 3; K. Cotter, 246
Excelsior, 23 m., 50 s., 4.

5.

(1 lap), 47 m. 50s., (2: C. Childs

GRASS TRACK RACING
M. Hayes takes two
mile title
The two mile 500 c.c. grass-
track championship of the
Southern Centre Motor Cycle Union
of Ireland, contested at the Irish
M.C.C. meeting at Terenure College,
Dublin. yesterday, was a very fast
race, mainly fought out by Ian
Willliams (Ariel) and Mercyn Hapes
(J.A.P.), who outpaced the Belfast
rider, W J. Agnew (J.A.P.).
Williams made a good start and
led for the most of the race. but was
passed by Hayes on the last lap
and narrowly beaten.
Williams had previously beaten
Hayes in a graded scratch race,
which he won bt four seconds in
best time of the day 3m. 42s. He
collected another place when finish-
ing second from scratch in the
general handicap.
Southern Centre, M.C.U.I., 500 c.c.

Rider, machine
part company
A black and white up close photograph of Ian Williams seconds after a fall off his bike. Ian Williams is on the ground, while his bike is seen toppling through the field. In the background a man waving a flag runs towards the scene.
Ian Williams (Dublin) was
going well before taking this
tumble during the Irish cham-
pionships grass-track meeting,
organised by the Dublin and District Motor Cycle Club, at
Butlin's Holiday Camp, yester-
day. After examinations Ian was discovered to have broken
his collar bone.

Motor cycling
Long just
misses
hat-trick
DAVID LONG (Dodler) had a
most successful day at the
Irish M.C.C. grasstrack races at
Bloomfield, Merrion road, Dublin,
yesterday, winning the first race, a
graded scratch event, and the last,
the allcomers’ handicap, in which he
passed the limit man, C. O'Connor
(Francis-Barnett) at half-distance
and went on to win by nine seconds.
He nearly won the 250 c.c. scratch
race also, but was brought off on
the last lap by G. F. Scarlett (Dot),
who was attempting to pass him.
Fastest riders were the Williams
brothers, lan beating Eric to win
his graded scratch race in best time
of the day, 2m. 38s., and Eric turn-
ing the tables in the 500 c.c. scratch,
which he won in the same time.
Results :—
Graded Scratch Race A—1, D. Long
(247 Dodler); 2. C. O’Connor (197 F/
Barnett); 3, J. D. Roche (197 Dot). Win-
ner’s time, 3m. 3s.

B.S.A.): 2, J M. Kavanagh (249 F/Bar-
nett); 3. D. McGowan (348 B.S.A.). 2.49.

SUNDAY REVIEW
MOTOR-CYCLING...
BY BR
Big Test
Nenagh
AT three o’clock this afternoon, the first 1958
motor-cycle grass-track event will get
under way at Drummin Field, just outside
Nenagh town.
This is the first time that
such an honour has fallen
to a provincial club.
And it is due to the fact
that the I.M.C.C Irish Motorcycle Club . date
scheduled for yesterday was
abandoned because the usual
course at Hazelhatch was
not available.
The Ormond M.C.C. Motorcycle Club , who
organise to-day’s event, are a
newly-formed club and have
never run any kind of
open event before.
DOT TWINS
Some idea of the fare to
be expected can be had from
the performances in last
week’s Dunlop scramble.
Chief interest is in the
250 c.c. class, where the
newly imported Dot twins in the hands of Jack Kavenagh
and Gerald Scarlett do battle
with the new A.M.C. Associated Motorcycles engined
Francis Barnetts, ridden by
Ian Williams and Jim
Kavenagh.
Ian Williams is Ariel-
mounted in the 500 c.c. class.
The competition comes
from his brother, Eric, who
rides either an Ariel or a
JAP-engined special, and
George Harps, also Ariel-
mounted.
Dermot Byrne rides his
recently acquired JAP.
LOCAL MEN
Local interest is in
Dalcassian Dalcassian Motorcycle Club riders McEoin
(James), Kelly (James), Len-
non (Norton).
Early entries close to-
morrow for the Limerick
Motor Club’s Circuit of
Munster, the annual car
rally held over the Whit
week-end.
This year’s event takes the
same form as that of pre-
vious years—about 600 miles
of driving in two days.
here are four starting
points — Cork, Limerick,
Dublin, and Urlingford.
BIG ENTRY
THERE is a big entry for
the Athlone Hockey
Club’s annual mixed 6-a-side
tournament at Grace Park,
Athlone, to-day.
Isle of Man Win
For Miller?
THIS week sees the annual mecca of motor-
cyclists in full swing. The Isle of Man
TT Tourist Trophy week is just as attractive as ever and Irish-
men are likely to be as prominent as usual.
We stand a good chance
of seeing Sammy Miller
finish in front this year.
He will be riding a 125 c.c
Ducati in the ultra light-
weight event over Clypse
on Wednesday.
In the 250 c.c. event he
rides a Czechoslovakian CZ
and his competition will
include two other Ulster
riders who should not be too
far behind—Tommy Robb
and Davy Andrews, who
ride N.S.U.s entered by
Tommy Hill.
FAVOURITE
Another Ulsterman rides
in both senior and junior
events on an A.J.S. (350)
and a Norton (500).
Judging by practice times
last week, it seems that John
must be a favourite for the senior honours of the
week on a works M.V.
Augusta.
Irish fans, returning from
the Island immediately after
the I.O.M. Isle of Man racing, will
move straight to Butlin’s
Holiday Camp, Mosney,
where the Dublin and Dis-
trict M.C.C. Motorcycle Club
hold their
annual championship meet-
ing next Saturday.
BIG SURPRISE
Included in the programme
will be the National two-
mile 500 c.c. and 250 c.c.
championships, as well as
the 350 c.c. southern centre
one.
I expect Davy Dixon to
retain this title, but if a
southerner comes out on top
in either of the others it will
be a big surprise.
A black and white up close photograph of Sammy Miller wearing a white racing helmet and goggles (positioned on the helmet). A 'cut' located in the third column (top) of the article 10.3, "Islse of Man for Miller"
SAMMY MILLER
Ian Williams, on the
Francis Barnett, might just
manage it in the 250 race.
Racing starts at 3.30 and
will conclude at about
5.45 p.m.
Powerscourt '56
